title.value: Influence of scanning plane on Human Spinal Cord functional Magnetic Resonance echo planar imaging
title.justification: This is the title as given in the user prompt and it sufficiently represents the content of the paper.
title.quote: Influence of scanning plane on Human Spinal Cord functional Magnetic Resonance echo planar imaging

extractions.description: The paper explores the influence of scanning planes (axial vs. sagittal) on spinal cord fMRI data quality and reproducibility.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments with human subjects to compare scanning planes, thus it is empirical.
type.quote: METHODS: Forty-five healthy subjects underwent MRI acquisition in a Philips Achieva 3T MRI scanner.

name.justification: The paper focuses on improving functional MRI techniques specifically for spinal cord imaging.
name.quote: Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) is based on the Blood Oxygenation Level Dependent contrast and has been exploited for the indirect study of neuronal activity within both the brain and the spinal cord.

name.justification: The study targets fMRI and its application in scanning different planes of the spinal cord.
name.quote: This study was aimed at systematically verifying whether sagittal scanning in scfMRI using EPI readout is a viable alternative to the more common axial scanning.

name.justification: The dataset was used to assist the functional response analysis.
name.quote: A different approach to cope with the influence of surrounding tissue is acquiring along the sagittal plane with anisotropic voxels to optimize the sampling matrix according to the natural geometry of the SC.

name.justification: RETROICOR was applied for noise correction using recorded pulse and respiration data.
name.quote: RETROICOR noise correction was applied to each functional run, using recorded pulse and respiration data.
